main_text.text: So far in the past two weeks we have covered this paradigm of the greedy paradigm.
main_text.speaker: A

main_text.text: The idea is to make some quick decision in terms of what's going to be the solution.
main_text.speaker: A

main_text.text: Never change your mind on that, never go back and redo it.
main_text.speaker: A

main_text.text: So those algorithms are usually very fast, very efficient, because we don't do any global analysis, as opposed to the other extreme exhaustive search where we look at the entire search space.
main_text.speaker: A

main_text.text: That's going to be very slow with greedy because we make quick local decisions, sometimes the proof of correctness is going to be harder than average.
main_text.speaker: A

main_text.text: The other extreme exhaustive search, you are looking at every possibility.
main_text.speaker: A

main_text.text: So one of them has to be optimal.
main_text.speaker: A

main_text.text: So the proof is almost trivial.
main_text.speaker: A

main_text.text: But the algorithms are very slow to the extent that they are not practical.
main_text.speaker: A

main_text.text: Usually they are exponential time, n, factorial 2 to the n, etc.
main_text.speaker: A

main_text.text: So in some sense, 3D might be the other extreme of exhaustive search.
